message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: RT to Win! Predicting Message Propagation in Twitter
Paper Abstract: Twitter is a very popular way for people to share information on a bewildering multitude of topics. Tweets are propagated using a variety of channels: by following users or lists, by searching or by retweeting. Of these vectors, retweeting is arguably the most effective, as it can potentially reach the most people, given its viral nature. A key task is predicting if a tweet will be retweeted, and solving this problem furthers our understanding of message propagation within large user communities. We carry out a human experiment on the task of deciding whether a tweet will be retweeted which shows that the task is possible, as human performance levels are much above chance. Using a machine learning approach based on the passive-aggressive algorithm, we are able to automatically predict retweets as well as humans. Analyzing the learned model, we find that performance is dominated by social features, but that tweet features add a substantial boost.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the **passive-aggressive algorithm**:

The passive-aggressive regressor is mentioned as one of the out-of-core regression implementations available in scikit-learn, a popular machine learning library.

Passive Aggressive is also listed as one of the multi-classification algorithms supported by Jubatus, an open-source online machine learning and distributed computing framework.

The passive-aggressive algorithm is a machine learning algorithm used in the context of **online learning**, which is a method of machine learning in which data becomes available in a sequential order and is used to update the best predictor for future data at each step, as opposed to batch learning techniques.

The algorithm is particularly useful in scenarios where it is computationally infeasible to train over the entire dataset, or when it is necessary for the algorithm to dynamically adapt to new patterns in the data, or when the data itself is generated as a function of time.

If you'd like more specific technical details about how the passive-aggressive algorithm works or its mathematical formulation, I'd be happy to search for more detailed information.

I've completed a web search for "machine learning". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.(no content)In supervised learning, an algorithm is provided with labeled samples. For instance, the samples might be descriptions of mushrooms, with labels indicating whether they are edible or not. The algorithm uses these labeled samples to create a classifier. This classifier assigns labels to new samples, including those it has not previously encountered.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## History

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Twitter:

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Key Features

Users could share concise text messages, images, and videos through "tweets" and engage with other users' content via likes or "retweets".(no content)Users can group posts together by topic or type by use of hashtags – words or phrases prefixed with a "#" sign. Similarly, the "@" sign followed by a username is used for mentioning or replying to other users.

## History and Development

Twitter's origins lie in a "daylong brainstorming session" held by board members of the podcasting company Odeo. Jack Dorsey, then an undergraduate student at New York University, introduced the idea of an individual using an SMS service to communicate with a small group. Work on the project started in February 2006.(no content)The company had its initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange on November 7, 2013.(no content)Twitter was an American social networking service that was rebranded as X in 2023.

## Notable Features and Services

The platform has evolved to include various features such as Twitter Spaces, a social audio feature that enables users to host or participate in a live-audio virtual environment call.

Web search results for query: "retweet"

Links: [{"title":"List of most-retweeted tweets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_most-retweeted_tweets"},{"title":"Tweet (social media) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tweet_(social_media)"},{"title":"Reblogging - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reblogging"},{"title":"Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"},{"title":"List of Twitter features - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_trends"},{"title":"Ameronothrus retweet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ameronothrus_retweet"},{"title":"Twitter usage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_usage"},{"title":"Template:Cite tweet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Cite_tweet"},{"title":"Twitter use by Donald Trump - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_use_by_Donald_Trump"},{"title":"Twitter bot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_bot"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about retweeting:

## Definition

A retweet (officially reposting since July 2023) is the mechanism that allows users to repost the content of another user's post with an indication that the source of the post is another user.

## History

The "retweet" phenomenon began in March 2007, when an informal protocol slowly developed among Twitter users. Initially called an "echo" the first instance was by Narendra Rocherolle, and a month later the term "retweet" was first referenced.(no content)In this protocol, a post by User A which was considered notable by another Twitter user, User B, was copied by User B and reposted under User B's account and prefixed with "RT @username", with "RT" meaning "retweet".(no content)In November 2009, Twitter began rolling out the ability to 'retweet' a tweet. Prior to this, people would write "RT @username" before quoting the original tweet.

## Evolution

In April 2015, the "quote retweet" (also known as "Quote RTs" or "QRT") was introduced, with users able to retweet a post with their own commentary added above the original content. In August 2020, a "Quote Tweets" link was added under posts to allow users to see other users' quote retweets.(no content)In 2023, with the rebranding of Twitter to X, "retweets" were quietly renamed to "reposts"; however, "retweets" remained the most commonly used term on the site.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about message propagation networks:

## Key Areas Related to Message Propagation Networks

**1. Belief Propagation & Message Passing in Graphical Models**

Belief propagation, also known as sum–product message passing, is a message-passing algorithm for performing inference on graphical models, such as Bayesian networks and Markov random fields.(no content)The algorithm works by passing real valued functions called messages along the edges between the nodes, making it fundamental to probabilistic inference.

**2. Message Passing in Neural Networks**

Message passing can be formally expressed as message passing neural networks (MPNNs).(no content)In a message passing layer, nodes update their representations by aggregating the messages received from their immediate neighbours. This approach is widely used in graph neural networks for various applications.

**3. Message Passing in Computer Science**

In computer science, message passing is a technique for invoking behavior on a computer, where the invoking program sends a message to a process and relies on that process and its supporting infrastructure to then select and run some appropriate code.(no content)Message passing is ubiquitous in modern computer software and is used as a way for the objects that make up a program to work with each other and as a means for objects and systems running on different computers to interact.

**4. Message Switching Networks**

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of text classification prediction:

## Overview

Text classification (or document classification) is a problem in library science, information science and computer science, where the task is to assign a document to one or more classes or categories.(no content)This may be done "manually" (or "intellectually") or algorithmically.

## How It Works

A typical application is to scan a set of documents written in a natural language and either model the document set for predictive classification purposes or populate a database or search index with the information extracted.(no content)Text analysis involves information retrieval, lexical analysis, pattern recognition, tagging/annotation, information extraction, and data mining techniques, with the overarching goal being to turn text into data for analysis, via the application of natural language processing (NLP), different types of algorithms and analytical methods.

## Common Applications

Automatic document classification techniques include email routing, language identification, genre classification, readability assessment, and sentiment analysis. Additionally, Naive Bayes classifiers are a popular statistical technique of email filtering, typically using bag-of-words features to identify email spam, an approach commonly used in text classification.

## Classification Methods

Text documents are classified into target categories using synonym-based classifiers or statistical classifiers, such as Naive Bayes (NB) and Support Vector Machines (SVMs).

Links: [{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Social network analysis software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis_software"},{"title":"International Network for Social Network Analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Network_for_Social_Network_Analysis"},{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"Social network analysis in criminology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis_in_criminology"},{"title":"Dynamic network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_network_analysis"},{"title":"Semantic social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_social_network"},{"title":"Network homophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_homophily"},{"title":"Cognitive social structures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_social_structures"},{"title":"Duocentric social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duocentric_social_network"}]

I've completed a web search for "social network analysis." Here's a comprehensive overview of the results:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory.(no content)It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

## Applications

Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, meme proliferation, information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships.(no content)Social network analysis has found applications in various academic disciplines as well as practical contexts such as countering money laundering and terrorism.

## Visualization

These networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines. These visualizations provide a means of qualitatively assessing networks by varying the visual representation of their nodes and edges to reflect attributes of interest.

## Key Metrics

Metrics encountered in social network analysis include those measuring the size, the nature of connections between members being analyzed, distribution, and segmentation - including subsets such as multiplexity, propinquity, density, centrality, and cohesion.

## Historical Development

Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim, who wrote about the importance of studying patterns of relationships that connect social actors. In 1934 Jacob Moreno and Helen Jennings introduced basic analytical methods.

I've completed a web search for "social network analysis." Here's a comprehensive overview of the results:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory.(no content)It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

## Applications

Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, meme proliferation, information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships.(no content)Social network analysis has found applications in various academic disciplines as well as practical contexts such as countering money laundering and terrorism.

## Visualization

These networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines. These visualizations provide a means of qualitatively assessing networks by varying the visual representation of their nodes and edges to reflect attributes of interest.

## Key Metrics

Metrics encountered in social network analysis include those measuring the size, the nature of connections between members being analyzed, distribution, and segmentation - including subsets such as multiplexity, propinquity, density, centrality, and cohesion.

## Historical Development

Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim, who wrote about the importance of studying patterns of relationships that connect social actors. In 1934 Jacob Moreno and Helen Jennings introduced basic analytical methods.

I've found comprehensive information about online learning algorithms. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Online machine learning is a method of machine learning in which data becomes available in a sequential order and is used to update the best predictor for future data at each step, as opposed to batch learning techniques which generate the best predictor by learning on the entire training data set at once.

## Key Characteristics

In computer science, an online algorithm is one that can process its input piece-by-piece in a serial fashion, i.e., in the order that the input is fed to the algorithm, without having the entire input available from the start.

## Applications and Use Cases

Online learning is a common technique used in areas of machine learning where it is computationally infeasible to train over the entire dataset, requiring the need of out-of-core algorithms. It is also used in situations where it is necessary for the algorithm to dynamically adapt to new patterns in the data, or when the data itself is generated as a function of time, e.g., prediction of prices in the financial international markets.(no content)Online machine learning algorithms find applications in a wide variety of fields such as sponsored search to maximize ad revenue, portfolio optimization, shortest path prediction (with stochastic weights, e.g. traffic on roads for a maps application), spam filtering, real-time fraud detection, dynamic pricing for e-commerce, etc.

## Challenges

Online learning algorithms may be prone to catastrophic interference, a problem that can be addressed by incremental learning approaches.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "RT to Win! Predicting Message Propagation in Twitter". Here's a summary:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes a novel machine learning approach)

**Key Findings:**

The paper has been analyzed and 8 triples have been identified and validated:

1. **Twitter** (tool) - The social media platform being analyzed
2. **Tweet (social media)** (data) - The fundamental data units analyzed
3. **Machine learning** (method) - Core methodology for prediction
4. **Online machine learning** (method) - Novel application of online learning
5. **Document classification** (task) - Related classification problem
6. **Social network analysis** (method) - Used to extract social features
7. **Prediction** (task) - Core task of predicting retweets
8. **Supervised learning** (method) - Training approach used

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed successfully
- Paper Type: contribution
- Triples: 8
- Entity Types Distribution: 1 tool, 1 data, 4 methods, 2 tasks
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and correct

The analysis shows that this paper makes a contribution by proposing an online machine learning approach (passive-aggressive algorithm) to predict tweet retweets, combining both social network features and tweet content features for improved prediction performance.

Sources:
- [Twitter - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter)
- [Tweet (social media) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tweet_(social_media))
- [Machine learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning)
- [Online machine learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_machine_learning)
- [Document classification - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_classification)
- [Social network analysis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis)
- [Prediction - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prediction)
- [Supervised learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervised_learning)
